answers.answer: Don't know what happened . . .sorry.
You only see one post on this side?And nothing on the other?Uh -oh.thanks for letting me know.wyntre

i had symptoms as you describe, but not during tx.  as an afterthought, it was probably some of the manifestations of something going wrong with my body and i now think it was the hep c, but no way to be certain.i once worked in a board & care and while filling the meds, bottles would fly out of my hand - it was really strange like i was possessed, had joint probs, and couldn't open jars, that is when a rhematologist tried to tell me i had fibromyalgia, and put me on low dose of neurontin, which would help me through these mysterious sx.  i would get this in flareups that would last some weeks then disappear.  i would take the neurontin only as needed.i am aware from reading various material that one can get neuropathy during tx.  and that for some this could be permanent condition. others may know more specific.by the way i no longer have the problem above mentioned and felt that chiropractice adj. had resolved it way before the hep c tx. perhaps out in both upper back/neck and lower back saccroilliac (tail bone).
What you have is a condition called Peripheral Neuropathy, Neuropathy is a medical term for any disease of the nerves.  There are four major forms of neuropathy

Thanks for the info.  I pulled up some stuff online, as well.But what if you NEVER had these sensations before starting TX?  (I started December 2006).Do you think the drugs (peg/riba/neupogen) can cause the symptoms and they go away when you stop TX?Or, can TX cause this condition?Thanks again for you help.This is the first time in my life I have ever felt like this.wyntreps - i'm gonna read the article
Can you post links to the articles that mentioned tx related neuropathy?thanks.wyn

Hi Wyn.  It look like this study below was designed to answer the question of whether IFN/combo tx could actually cause peripheral neuropathy.  They concluded  no.  I have never heard of an ancdotal story of peripheral nerve pain triggered by combo tx.   Though I suppose it possible.  The neuropathy is alway characterized as being caused by the alien virus in the bloodstream,endin up in as  painful vasulitis in the smallest vessesls at the periphery of our arms and legs.   Can you get to see an rheumatologist?  Do you have purple rashy cutaneous manifestations of cryoglobulins on your feet or ankles?  I had peripheral nueropathy before treatment, very mild skin issues, and they have resolved.Keep us posted Wyn.  I am so glad you are undectable! Wheeew!You too Debby New York Sport Car Chick!! Life is good  :-)CheersKit07From this article:"CONCLUSIONS: Pegylated interferon alpha therapy was notassociated with the occurrence (or worsening) of peripheral neuropathy orantibodies to peripheral nerve antigens in patients with hepatitis C virus."Peripheral neurotoxicity of pegylated interferon alpha: a prospective study inpatients with HCV.  Neurology. 2006 Sep 12;67(5):781-5.OBJECTIVE: To assess whether pegylated interferon alpha (PEG-IFNalpha) mayinduce peripheral neuropathy or antibodies to peripheral nerve antigens inpatients with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. METHODS: We studied 52 patientswith HCV (38 men, 14 women; mean age 44.6  10.6 years) treated with IFNalpha.Before therapy (T(0)), patients underwent quantitative viral RNA determination,HCV genotype analysis, and neurologic and electrophysiologic evaluation. At theend (T(1)) and after therapy (T(2)), patients were neurologically andelectrophysiologically re-evaluated. Antibodies to gangliosides and sulfatideswere assayed by ELISA at T(0) and T(1). Twenty-three patients with HCV withcomparable age, viral load, and genotype, not treated with IFNalpha, werestudied as controls. RESULTS: Seven patients (six in IFNalpha, one control) hadperipheral neuropathy at recruitment. No significant differences in theelectrophysiologic measures were detected between T(0) and T(1)(repeated-measures analysis of variance [ANOVA]) in any of the 52 patients or inthose with neuropathy at T(0). No changes were found at T(2), independent of theviral response to treatment. Two patients, one with neuropathy, hadantiganglioside antibodies at recruitment. Two patients, one not treated withIFNalpha, developed low antibody titers during follow-up, without symptoms orsigns of neuropathy. CONCLUSIONS: Pegylated interferon alpha therapy was notassociated with the occurrence (or worsening) of peripheral neuropathy orantibodies to peripheral nerve antigens in patients with hepatitis C virus.

Hi again, I am now 3 years post tx, and in the last 4 months I have had the problems with the legs, aching all the time, sharp pains, constant, I didnt know what it was till I came across that article and it sorta fell into place, something else to ask the doc at the  next visit.
here is another link:http://www.neuropathy.org/site/PageServer

Thanks both for the additional info.I'm going to check the article and the link, laterMaybe I'm just getting a little paranoid, here, but it's good to be able to read the FAQS!kit, thanks for remebering I reached UND.  I just found out Monday that it was sometime between week 16 and 18, although, since week 16 showed VL of 90, I've read that's almost statistically meaningless so maybe I got UND sooner.that's the great news.the bad news is 52 more weeks!!!!!So you'll be hearing WAAAAYYYY more than you ever wanted want to about my condition!  *LOL*wyntre

here is another link from National institute of Health NIH, it is not too recent, and what it says is that it happens infrequently, and not much info on it.http://gateway.nlm.nih.gov/MeetingAbstracts/102259356.htmlwhile i do appreciate i feel better look better and believe the virus is gone, i don't always feel trustful of pharms... its all about the money so they don't want us to know everything.just yesterday i heard on news of pharms stiffling findings of the addictiveness of oxycontin so they could make a bigger buck (and pass the FDA maybe) and there was another one a few years back was it valprexia??? one of the arthritis meds (i forget what it was) was taken off market very suddenly.
Thanks for the info.Luckily (for me) i DON'T have those SX.How are you feeling, otherwise, post tx?wyntre
here is a link..references interferon.http://www.chemocare.com/managing/numbness__tingling.asp

The body's nervous system is divided into two major systems; the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system.  The peripheral nervous system is also divided into two major parts, the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system.   The somatic nervous system consists of peripheral nerve fibers that send sensory information to the central nervous system and motor nerve fibers that send signals to skeletal muscle.  The autonomic nervous system controls smooth muscle of the viscera (internal organs) and glands.Peripheral neuropathy results from some type of damage to the peripheral nerves.  Certain chemotherapy drugs can cause peripheral neuropathy such as vinca alkaloids (vincristine), cisplatin, paclitaxel, and the podophyllotoxins (etoposide and tenoposide).Other drugs used to treat cancer such as thalidomide and interferon also can cause peripheral neuropathy.Individuals at greatest risk of peripheral neuropathy associated with chemotherapy are those with preexisting peripheral neuropathy from conditions such as:

Towards the end of my tx, I developed what I thought may be Neuropathy. In cool weather, my fingers would become numb and tingle and when I pressed lightly on them, they turned white. This never happened before tx. I did some searching and on another Hep site I read about Raynaud
Thanks for the links.  I'm gonna check them now.wyntre

"Although some of the signs of neuropathy may appear suddenly, this change in sensation usually builds gradually and can worsen with each additional dose of chemotherapy.  It is usually strongest right after a chemo treatment, but tends to lessen just before the next treatment."Yup - that's what's happening."The symptoms usually peak about 3-5 months after the last dose of treatment is taken."Thanks agian.Need all the confirmation i can get that I'm not outta my mind!wyntre

The other article was interesting (even though it's from 2002) in mentioning two of the cases got worse around week 18.That's when it started with me.Also, this is good info:"Due to its insidous onset, we advise special care on the mild initial symptoms of neuropathy during treatment with Peg-IFN."thanks again,wyn

I was so surprised to see this post.  I was just telling a friend of mine that I'm noticing a little tingling in my hands.  At first I thought it was due to the anemia but I have it even when I'm just sitting and resting.  I've only been treating a couple weeks and it started about a week ago.  This did not happen to me the last time I treated.  Once again, it's nice to find out it not just me!!

i am glad you found this helpful. i am w/hmo that gave me a lot of packets and i participated in a group presentation. i believe they did inform me of this "rare" symptom - they say affects less than 1% (going from memory), others not in such a program may not have been as informed by their dr.again i think it could be rare, but also think could be way the pharms take some spotlight off the undesirable sides.some info i found was through "chemotherapy" search which of course pulls up cancer sites, but interferon is also used for leukemia (i think) so we can find references for it there.  it makes sense also that most of the sides we have are also referenced there.  cancer gets way more attention than hep c

question: (I posted on the other side, too)Has anyone has these symptoms while on TX?They're associated with neuropathy. Can TX cause this?". . .spontaneous sensations, called paresthesias which include numbness, tingling, pins and needles, prickling, burning, cold, pinching, sharp, deep stabs, electric shocks, or buzzing.""...leg symptoms include difficulty walking or running, "heaviness" , it takes lots of effort just to climb the stairs and stumbling or tiring easily.""In the arms, difficulties with carrying a load of groceries, opening jars, turning door knobs."I'm a little scared about this.wyntre
title: neuropathy as TX SX
